content_block_static.static_content:
System Scope

ARMS is used for setting up and closing down privileged accounts, both administrator accounts and service accounts, for use by DXC personnel in managing client's systems and services.  

 

ARMS does not cater for managing access rights for

  • end users; nor
  • third party personnel; nor
  • privileged access by DXC staff to DXC internal systems; nor
  • end user access to applications; nor
  • VPN access to the client infrastructure.

These are covered by separate processes and, in some cases, supporting applications.

 

Key objectives

The key aims of ARMS are to

  1. provide a proper system of authority for privileged accounts, so no rights are established without the express permission of DXC management;
  2. enforce the security principle of Segregation of Duties. Hence an Administrator cannot request ask for access rights for themselves.      Rather their manager, the ‘Requestor’, must raise a request for a member of their staff, the Administrator, to have access rights;   
  3. enforce compliance to client information security policy and data, particularly the BT Access Control Policy, BT Access Control Management Standard and the BT Password Management Standard;
  4. automate and safeguard record keeping of request and approvals, as evidence of due process to BT management and auditors;
  5. to minimize the effort on the part of CSC managers and administrators to create, extend and remove access rights of their staff, and without them needing to keep records or remember to renew and review accounts;
  6. enforce the security principle of Least Privilegee. ARMS can identify and respond to situations where the Administrator may not need or should no longer have their access rights;
  7. implement recommendations made by BT, CASRA and external auditors; and
  8. enforce good security practice, e.g. in complying with the principles of ISO 27001.
